title: 108_s2903
content: The Act may be cited as the "Nonprofit Athletic Organization Protection Act of 2004". Congress finds that amateur sports and education-based athletics are important for youth development, academic achievement, and social skills. Nonprofit organizations play a key role in promoting the well-being of young athletes, despite the inherent risks of injuries. Participation in sports leads to lower levels of obesity, better health in adulthood, and the necessity of playing rules in amateur sports. Participation in amateur athletics promotes youth development, academic achievement, and social skills. It leads to lower obesity levels and better health in adulthood. Rules in sports are necessary for age-appropriate competition and involve tradeoffs. Lawsuits against rule makers for negligence are deemed unfair. Lawsuits against rules makers for negligence in amateur sports can have a detrimental impact on their ability to provide services and discourage experienced individuals from serving on rules committees. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "economic loss" refers to pecuniary loss from harm, "harm" includes various types of losses, "noneconomic loss" encompasses nonpecuniary losses, and "nonprofit organization" is defined as specified. The term "nonprofit organization" is defined as an organization exempt from tax under section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code, or a not-for-profit organization operated primarily for charitable, civic, educational, religious, welfare, or health purposes. A "nonprofit athletic organization" is a nonprofit organization that adopts rules for athletic competitions. A nonprofit athletic organization is defined as a nonprofit organization that sets rules for athletic competitions. The term "State" includes the District of Columbia and any commonwealth, territory, or possession of the United States. SEC. 4. LIMITATION ON LIABILITY FOR NONPROFIT ATHLETIC ORGANIZATIONS. Liability Protection for Nonprofit Athletic Organizations: A nonprofit athletic organization is not liable for harm caused by its actions in adopting rules for sanctioned competitions or practices, as long as it was acting within its duties, properly licensed, and the harm was not due to willful misconduct or negligence. Nonprofit athletic organizations are protected from liability if harm is not caused by willful misconduct, gross negligence, or reckless misconduct. Employees, agents, and volunteers are still responsible, and exceptions to liability protection include adherence to risk management procedures and being liable for the acts of employees, agents, and volunteers. The limitation on liability for nonprofit athletic organizations does not apply to certain claims under federal, state, or local laws, including antitrust, labor, environmental, defamation, tortious interference of contract law, civil rights law, and discrimination protection. SEC. 5. PREEMPTION. This Act preempts State laws inconsistent with it, except for laws providing extra liability protection for nonprofit athletic organizations' rule-making activities. SEC. 6. EFFECTIVE DATE. This Act takes effect upon enactment and applies to claims for harm caused by nonprofit athletic organizations filed after the effective date, only if the harm or conduct occurred after that date.
